posts.name: Nathaniel
posts.cooked: My team has historically used SPARK MAX motor controllers along with NEOs & the REV Through Bore encoders. Recently, we purchased 2 Krakens. Personally, I’m not a huge fan of the krakens and believe that more NEOs would work just fine, and be more cost-effective, but I was outvoted. Since I’ll have to program our elevator next year (that’s what the two Krakens are planned for use on), and the 2 would be our only CTRE devices that would need licensing, I was wondering if the $20/yr fee was justifiable. I did find the cost breakdown on the CTRE site, but it’s confusing. Does the ability to control torque actually have a big impact? That and the lower power draw seems to be the main selling point.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
It depends a lot on what you want to use the motors for, but if you’re only going to have two of them it doesn’t make a lot of sense to me.

Have you considered the Talon FXS?  That would let you continue using your existing stock of NEO motors with CTRE ’s better API.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked: I would not buy Phoenix Pro if I were you; it can be useful for very advanced teams, but most teams don’t need the features.

posts.name: Nathaniel
posts.cooked: I’m not sure that the cost-to-value proposition of the FXS would be worth it for us – and my team seems fully sold on Krakens. They are of the “don’t spend a penny more than absolutely necessary” mentality - except, it seems, when it comes to mechanical! I appreciate the advice but I don’t think I could convince them to purchase anything other than Krakens, so I think I’ll have to work with what I can get. I think their main gripe with NEOs are that they require external motor controllers in the first place.

posts.name: Rich Jr
posts.cooked: Agreed with the above, Pro gets more interesting when you have the full ecosystem (CANivore, CANCoders, etc).

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC 271 | Lead Mentor | Fabworks Discount Code: FRC271

posts.name: Nathaniel
posts.cooked: We do have CANCoders for our swerve (uses NEOs), but we use REV products for everything else and I don’t think that Pro would do much for encoders.

posts.name: Rich Jr
posts.cooked:
Correct, you would need the TalonFX (Krakens) on the same mechanism as the CANcoder to make use of the Fused/Synced sensor features you’d get with Pro.

If you haven’t seen this table yet it has a lot of information in it:

Phoenix 6 currently offers the following features and will further expand. Phoenix 6: The following features are available for free in the Phoenix 6 API. Comprehensive API: Device signal getters re...

Edit: One thing that isn’t immediately obvious by this chart but already mentioned in this thread is that the torque control modes require FOC which you get with Pro.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC 271 | Lead Mentor | Fabworks Discount Code: FRC271

posts.name: Steven Carmain
posts.cooked:
We use the Pro license, we notice a lot better torque, especially in the low end.  The Neo Vortex wasn’t giving enough speed to fast spit a coral for us.  (We went Kraken district 1, Neo Vortex district 2, back to Kraken at states.)

Also the position control with FOC (just the emulated one, not full torque control) just felt better and faster. It definitely didn’t sag like the not pro device.

We got the season pass, but didn’t use any real advanced features.  Our pids are the same values as before Pro license.

We just got the season pass and activated all Krakens.  We probably only needed like 7 devices (4 swerves plus Elevator/Claw), so the Rio version was just easier.

I don’t like the concept of the season pass, isn’t 14 motors + 6 CanCoders + Pigeon, isn’t enough money, but the performance was noticeable.  After the season, you can put you robot in offseason team number mode (team number 9970-9999) and try it for free at your shop.

posts.name: Nathaniel
posts.cooked: Ah, interesting. So we’d have to use a CANCoder in conjunction with the Krakens. I don’t think that the extra precision would be super worth it, considering that’s $30 for the privilege of slightly more positional accuracy, lol. FOC /torque control seems interesting though, depends on the weight our motors will have to lift. I suppose as @Steven_Carmain suggested we’ll have to test under a offseason team number to see if the performance boost would be worth it for us.

posts.name: Nathaniel
posts.cooked:
I’ll definitely do some offseason testing, thanks for the idea. If the performance improvement is as significant as you say we’ll probably purchase Pro.

Edit: The pricing scheme does seem a bit predatory on CTRE ’s part.

Steven_Carmain:

we notice a lot better torque, especially in the low end.

You’re still getting current limited at the low end and FOC doesn’t change the kT value, (Nm of torque per amp of current draw) so you’re getting identical torque at low to medium speeds. However, FOC reduces the stator winding resistance through driving the stators more efficiently, which means a) The top end torque gets slightly better b) The motor generates less heat when running

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked:
TheComputer314:

FOC doesn’t change the kT value

FOC actually does increase the kT slightly in exchange for a slightly lower kV. So you get about 3% more torque at a given stator current, but a slightly lower free speed (5800 RPM compared to 6000 RPM ). With that said, the greatest gain is in efficiency, as that impacts heat generation and the supply current and power output throughout the motor curve.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.cooked:
bhall-ctre:

FOC actually does increase the kT slightly in exchange for a slightly lower kV.

Wait it does? Motor performance stats on ReCalc don’t show that.

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked:
nexnot:

I don’t think that Pro would do much for encoders.

A convenience that pro adds to cancoders is boot to absolute mode.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
A motor using FOC , even at stall, will on average have a magnetic field oriented closer to normal to the rotor field than a motor using simpler trapezoidal commutation.

This means you’ll get more torque for the same electrical inputs and outputs.  That’s where the efficiency gain comes from.

I wouldn’t use ReCalc as a basis for your understanding of, well, any of these things.  Those are just numbers in a database.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.cooked: That makes a lotta sense, I didn’t really think of it that way before.
